Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that Obama fired every Bush-appointed ambassador on the day he was elected office, when in fact he replaced most, but not all, of them.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or specific examples to back up the assertion that every Bush-appointed ambassador was fired.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Obama did not remove any of the career appointees to ambassadorships.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that firing ambassadors appointed by the previous administration is an unusual or improper action, without providing any context or justification for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the alternative explanation that the replacement of politically appointed ambassadors is a customary practice when a new president takes office.
